I'm a high schooler who goes to a school with an EBR (Evidence Based Reasoning) grading system.  For each test there is a scale for 1-4. 1 is developing, practically meaning you either didn't do the work or failed the test. A 2 is called approaching expectations, and it's anything from barely not failing to <90%. A 3 is called Meets Expectations. If you get a majority 3s in a standard or half in an increasing order (like 2-2-3-3) you can get a 3 for that standard. Every class has multiple standards. Some tests only count for one standard while others count for multiple. 4s do exist, and they're called Exceeding Expectations. You'd think it'd be worth it to get a 4, but it's only for your prude. In reality, they count for the exact same as a 3, but are a few times harder to get. Most of the time they require out of class understanding or skills that get taught later in class. For STEM classes, a 4 can only be achieved if you answer a level 4 question, which may not even be on a test. For all of semester 1 this year there has not been a level 4 question in my AP Calculus BC class or my AP Computer Science A class or my Principles of Engineering class.  For an example of how the system works, a calc test has 4 standards. Standards 1 & 2 are about actually solving the problem, standard 3 is about explanations, and standard 4 is about notation errors and the like. If you get a 3 for every standard, then you get an A. A single 2 for any standard is a B. Multiple 2s are a C. A single 1 in any standards is a D or F for the class.   For an English class however, the standards may work differently. In my AP Language and Composition course, there a 3 standards, with each test counting in only 1 standard due to their nature. Standard 1 deals with analyzing passages, and so only Rhetorical Analysis essays are placed there. Standard 2 is about participation, so discussion and reflection grades go here. Standard 3 is about writing, so all the argumentative essays and creative writing are lumped in there.   It's a complicated system unique to each class and is detrimental to the students taking it. It both makes it easy to scrape by if you're barely good enough at each standard and the teacher likes you. However, if the teacher doesn't like you, it's very easy to give you a 2 and block you from achieving an A. My school is very competitive and a B or less is sometimes a cause for teasing in friend groups and lowers your social standing. And don't get me started on parental pressure. Even if your parents stop pressuring you the pressure becomes self enforced.   A lot of other students I know cheat extensively on exams, from learning questions and answers for a math test or learning a prompt for an essay, or simply straight up lying to a teacher for an extension. A lot of people miss tests so they can take them later and have additional prep time. I don't know anyone who genuinely likes their classes and would go to them if they weren't required for college applications. Well, not technically required, but practically.  All of this basically ends up with students cheating, lying, working their butts off to get a grade that says that they simply met expectations. A grade that feels meaningless in a meaningless class. A majority of the people in my AP English class don't plan to go into a career anywhere near Language and Composition.   If you're curious, the school is Adlai E. Stevenson Highschool and the system is only in place because our principal gets money from it and from endorsing it. If your school is considering it, please either switch to another school or convince them not to. A longtime teacher left the school and published a report detailing all the issues with the system and why he left because of it.   TLDR: My school has a BS grading system that doesn't make sense and states that doing your all is simply "meeting expectations".

while your going to get advice from a lot of people (go into trades, stay out of credit cards) i might give strange advice: don't tie your sense of self worth to productivity. this is harder than it seems, but this means you will have a high self worth & strong sense of self, no matter how hard you work or how easy you take it. so many people are restless, unable to rest for fear of looking "soft".  in another way, it is really important to be realistic, but what is actually realistic? most people think they have an answer, but we never thought as a species that moving to a celestial body was "realistic". also, it's really important to find out the hidden upsides & downsides of things early, ask uncomfortable questions & foster life long curiosity. also, try as many things as you can while resting to protect against burnout. most people find a pattern & stick with it, even though time & again it's shown that people who relearn will ALWAYS do better.   get good & persistent at relearning & your future will be evergreen, no matter what your situation ends up being  (yes, even if your homeless theres things to relearn.)

I'm a teacher, and I'm so concerned for this generation. I see students falling into one of two groups. The first has absolutely zero ambition, no goals, and is chronically disassociated from reality, swiping through a screen until the end of time. The other group is driven by achievement and constantly chasing perfection. These are the "resume builders" as I call them, but the constant grind is driving them into depression and anxiety when they can't live up to their own expectations. I have students in 11th grade showing the same signs of chronic burnout that I had at 26 working four part time jobs. Its crazy....

The idea that Gen Z doesn't want to grow up is kinda absurd to me. I think it's more accurate to say that Gen Z is entirely and utterly jaded by the world we've been born into. The milestones/ teenage life that we see idealized in movies is just not possible anymore. Society hates teenagers now. I remember going to the mall in high school and after like 5 pm you had to be accompanied by an adult or you got kicked out. You want to walk somehwere so you don't have to beg your parents for a ride? It's 5 miles away and there's no sidewalks or trees for shade. We didn't design our neighbourhoods for playing basketball in the streets. Parents are too afraid to let kids out of their sights because everything on the internet is telling us to be afraid. Parents won't let their kids have sleepovers anymore and unfortunately their reasoning is valid. Plus they're tracking you with your phone, so sneaking out is a no go. Every mistake you make has consequences. I actually think that Gen Z feels the pressures of what they're supposed to feel at age 20-30 in middle school and high school but with none of the experience or economic backing. We're asking 12 year olds to test into special high schools just to get a shot at a good career. And it turns out that career isn't going to pay you enough to live anyway, if you get a job at all. I don't think Gen Z has the economic standing to take risks without major consequences. Even if you do everything right, you can barely afford to live. You literally have to be born into a good life.

Millennial here. I want to grow up. I have a Bachelor's and a Master's. I have been applying for jobs for 5 years. The reality is, the industry at large has changed. Getting a job feels impossible. I have a Master's. I got a contract job with Google. They laid me off in the middle of the day one month into my second contract. Since I haven't even gotten a phone call. This isn't a Gen Z problem. This is a everyone problem. I've seen so many people just unable to get jobs. You have 1000s of people applying to one job. A job that more then likely is just up to add more data to their database so they can sell it to other companies. Like that job listing might not even be real.

You've correctly identified all of the symptoms to the greater problem. Economic instability is the root of it all. We can't afford what we need. Minimum wage is a joke (it used to be the wage one man needed to provide for a family of four).   And the police state has gotten insane. We're over criminalized and penalized for existing. My friend had to pay $700 for not being up on their insurance and tags, plus their car got towed because it's city policy to tow the car for expired registration. What good does that do?   We don't have third spaces or walkable communities, so when and where are you going to socialize with people? Plus if you want kids, you're going to be further in debt than others your age. And you have no time because the culture encourages hyper vigilance for your kids. No wonder we have iPad babies, people are afraid to let their kids out into the world. Parentifying your kids is not the solution to that either, though.   On top of that, social media algorithms thrive on increasing division and keeping you addicted to your phone.   It's a cacophony of societal issues all piled up to create the mess we're in now.

I want to add for driving, that a lot of people just don't want a car and many are sick of how necessary they are in the US as well as all the harm they do (e.g. demolishing neighbourhoods and third spaces for highways and car parks, worse mental health, no exercise, unsafe to exist outside in any other way other than being in a car). Movements for better city planning and allowing people to use other modes of transport safely are becoming more popular especially with gen z.

Gen Z here.  99% of these issues stem from the insurmountable economic/financial disadvantage most of us face and are likely doomed to face for the rest of our lives until this country has a massive upheaval. Our generation isn't lazy, we probably work harder than any other generation in history. Most fellow Gen Zrs I know work multiple jobs, myself included, with some kind of entrepreneurial side hustle. Just to make ends meet (and even then it isn't enough).  Meanwhile we grow up on stories from Gen X and Boomers who bought their 500k-1m value house for a stick of gum and some paperclips "back in their day", and a car and supported an entire family all on a SINGLE part-time job at a factory that robots have since replaced.

All of this has to do with the economic state the US is in. No teenagers want to drive because car payments are insurance are through the roof. 25 year olds can‚Äôt buy houses because of how expensive the housing market is right now, let alone renting. Can you blame us? We stay on our phones because doing anything else requires money we don‚Äôt have.

I‚Äôm 21 and living through this right now, so here‚Äôs some perspective. Not all Gen Z who are ‚Äúbehind‚Äù by society‚Äôs invisible standards are lazy or coddled. A lot of us grew up in unstable homes, dealing with real issues way before we had the chance to even think about adulthood, let alone prepare for it.  And now we‚Äôre entering a world that‚Äôs changing faster than ever. I started out studying computer science, but with how quickly AI is advancing, I changed majors because I‚Äôm seriously worried about that future career becoming obsolete.  Especially for those of us who didn‚Äôt grow up with money, we‚Äôre hyper-aware of how one wrong move could ruin our lives. We don‚Äôt get the luxury of just ‚Äúpicking something and figuring it out later‚Äù like some older generations could.  So no.. we‚Äôre not just obsessed with skincare and vibes. Dismissing an entire generation with cheap shots doesn‚Äôt make you insightful. It just makes you part of the problem.
How are Gen Z supposed to become adults when every door into adult life has been violently slammed in their face?

I watched the whole video without interruption or looking at the comments,  and as a frequent viewer, I approach your content in good faith. But I think even if all the above issues were completely absent, the growing inequality of wealth, opportunity and even rights would still lead our young people to the same place... a place often of dread and even nihilism, despite their best efforts. I am a therapist working in an incredibly unaffordable city. I have several GenZ clients who are in challenging living situations because they can‚Äôt afford to rent an efficiency apartment on their own or qualify for livable shared spaces with friends or partners. They are stuck living with their parents, sometimes in places where they experienced trauma or abuse, or staying in abusive relationships because the thought of moving out, in this economy, causes more anxiety than the alternative. In therapy, we focus on empowerment, approaching and achieving milestones, celebrating small victories‚Ä¶ but all with the understanding that things are way harder than they should be, way harder than was promised, way harder than what they would‚Äôve had to contend with if they were coming of age in a pre-pandemic world. It‚Äôs easy to become hopeless when everything is inaccessible. The worst part is that no one seems to see or validate this, outside of their own generation. I feel like the theme of the video has been a little lost here. It isn't about Gen Z achieving economic-based milestones like buying a house, having kids, or advancing in their careers. Like I said, it's about social and emotional milestones. Getting your driver's license is not about whether you can afford a car or not; it's about wanting to take on adult responsibilities. As well, settling into a long-term relationship is not about economics, and finding a path in life is not about landing your dream career job. The economy is hindering Gen Z greatly, but that wasn't what the video was about. I'm not saying they can't get jobs or buy a house because they were coddled as children. In the same way, I'm not saying they can't pick a life path because car prices have inflated past affordability. There is some overlap, as you can see in the video, but I was trying to lean on the mindset side of things, which is why economics only got a shout-out at the end.

Just throwing in my two cents as a 20-year-old Gen Z living in Australia (not the US).  I‚Äôve got my licence, I‚Äôm juggling two jobs, and I‚Äôm currently studying at uni. On average, I work about 25 hours a week, split between data work at a hospital and shifts at Subway.  The reality is, I feel like I have to work this much just to have a shot at a decent future. Sure, I know people say you can take it slow‚Äîenjoy your 20s, then think about settling down in your late 20s or early 30s. But honestly, it feels like if I wait that long, I‚Äôll either fall behind or just end up in the same rat race as everyone else my age.  Where I live, house prices are through the roof. Even saving up a 20% deposit could mean scraping together $60‚Äì80k for a 40-year-old place that needs renos. It‚Äôs disheartening knowing things have been gradually declining for decades, and from where we stand, they‚Äôre not looking like they‚Äôll improve anytime soon.  We were brought up being told, ‚ÄúIf you work hard, you‚Äôll get there‚Äù‚Äîthat one day we‚Äôd be able to afford a home. But look around‚Äîhow many 25‚Äì35-year-olds (even people in their 40s) are still trying to break into the housing market? It‚Äôs getting worse, not better. And it makes you wonder‚Ä¶ if things are only going to keep sliding downhill, what‚Äôs the point in trying so hard?  So many people in my generation have already resigned themselves to throwing away their dreams in exchange for short-term comfort. Constant access to dopamine through social media, internet addiction, not bothering with school or seeking meaningful work‚Äîit's not laziness, it's survival in a system that‚Äôs felt rigged from the beginning.  We‚Äôve grown up under the pressure of impossible expectations while being handed fewer opportunities. We‚Äôre the product of a society that changed the rules, then told us we just weren‚Äôt trying hard enough.  I‚Äôd genuinely love to hear your thoughts on how you‚Äôd approach teaching or guiding my generation. What makes some people grind through the system, and others give up or tune out entirely? Is it upbringing, luck, resilience‚Äîor something deeper?

im a '99 gen z, and literally for as long as i can remember, i've been suicidally depressed. like literally my earliest in-motion memory (as in not a snapshot of a moment) is the night of my 9th birthday, typing up my first suicide note. the idea that gen Z are burnt out and depression is 100% the reality of the situation, and i can only imagine how much worse it got for everyone behind me. my experiences with tech were paced to my age in a way that felt manageable - i got my first nokia brick phone at 9 (most kids my age got them around 10-11), then used variations of that style of phone until i was 16 and leaving school. in my friendgroup at age 13, there was ONE kid with a smartphone out of like, 15 kids. that was average. now every single kid in a classroom has a phone and probably a tablet. the impact that alone has is genuinely immeasurable. my last year at school, they instituted a ban on taking photos on school property - within the same year we had an assembly about the topic of making deepfake p*rn of each other. years later, i attended a family funeral, and as the second-youngest person there at 20, i took my cousin outside for some air bc he was around 13-15. within 10 minutes of us leaving the adults behind, he pulled up a video on his iPhone of Elsa from frozen singing "F*ck my ass!" dubbed over let it go. at a FUNERAL.   i'm entirely unsurprised that my generation is full of depressed aimless wanders and burnt out overachievers, theres nothing on offer for any of us anymore. the impact that tech had on us was mostly negative, and i say that as someone who's terminally online and has been for over a decade. i've never had any direction in life, any wants or desires, and whenever i tried to voice that to adults as a kid/teen, i got told off for being "negative" and "being contrary" instead of being listened to and helped/guided. i also grew up with a decent amount of freedom and support to develop independence and confidence, but without any desires or goals, what's the point of it? i dont want to be independent, i want to not be here anymore!

THIS!  I'm a millennial too.  I went to school, graduated, paid off the debt, and did all of the "right" things.  I got married, had a kid, and just generally worked really hard.  And I have been paid for all of that with failure.  It took 5 years to land my first good-paying job.  3 years after that, covid hit, and the cost of living surpassed my salary overnight, so all of the things I had been saving up for (like a house) immediately became unobtainable.  Shortly after that, my husband dumped me, my kid, and our pets onto the street.  I had quit my job a year earlier because his job moved him 3 hours away, and now I'm stuck living with my mom (again) and wondering how I'm going to buy groceries for the week because, once again, I can't find a job.  Honestly, I don't blame Gen-Z for being unmotivated.  I personally have to fight myself to do anything; I have no motivation at all.  It's not just that I have a fear of failure, it's that success has always been just out of reach for one reason or another no matter what I tried to do about it.  I'm tired of working so hard to stay so stuck.  No one should have to work so hard to fail.  And to add insult to injury, so many people blame me for the failures saying I should have chosen better.  Someone in my career field could have bought a modest home 30 years ago.  As far as I can tell, the only "better" choice I could have made in life was to be born 30 years earlier.  It's not really a great incentive to make success impossible to achieve and then blame the person struggling for not choosing a different impossible path.  And Gen-Z isn't stupid.  Part of the reason they can't choose is because they know that they will be slammed into the ground and blamed for their failure no matter what they do.

This was difficult to adjust to after growing up in a family who owned multiple homes, lived in the same place before for 11 years, and had a dad that had had such solid work that he could afford our same lifestyle even when he had to lose his ability to work for a few years there. I had been on a track to own my own home by the time I was 24, but bc of the economy/ etc., I am now 33 and live on gov help. I get blamed a lot too, even as, by now, I've  faced everything from a job moving overseas, age discrimination that my past workplace has had to pay out a lawsuit for, workplace harassment, gender discrimination, a person following me from my workplace, a business of my own not working out, and a bunch of other things. Trust me, they have no idea what they are talking about when they judge you and act like you haven't tried. I hear you. Please don't give up, especially for your child. I hope the best for all of us.

‚Äã¬†@UnGatoDeOro¬†I don't know about the author of the comment, but as a fellow Eastern European, I want to pitch in.  Fear was a big part of my responsible behavior when I was a child. Corporal punishment is a big and normal part of parenting in many Slavic cultures. I remember being in first grade, and being asked by our teacher to raise our hand if our parents don't use corporal punishment. Two children out of thirty raised their hand, and I know for a fact that one of those two  also got corporal punishment very occasionally, maybe 3 times in her life by the age of 6.  I was folding laundry because I would be spanked otherwise. I was helping with dishes because I would be beaten and ridiculed and made fun of otherwise.   And guess what? I have the same struggle with growing up as the other older gen Z has (born 1997), and I think it's because of two reasons.  1)  Having more responsibilities as a child didn't transform into having more freedoms. Also, I didn't really learn how to stand up for myself, because even though I was left to deal with my own problems, I could never stand up to my parents because I would be beaten if I did. 2) the economy is fucked, the only single people I know who don't live with 3 roommates are people who live in a countryside and work remote, precisely as a cheap labour for some big tech company.

Hi! I just wanted to give a few ideas of some free or low cost things I used to do in my early 20s while in grad school that hopefully will help :) Obviously, this is based on my experience of access to things in my city but these are things I used to do to save money because cocktails and ubers were expensive. Going on jogs or walks with people on a trail or in a park. Instead of happy hours me and my friends would have "healthy hours" and go to the gym together in our apartment gyms that came free with rent. Instead of getting drinks, we'd get a latte or hot chocolate for a few dollars and window shop. Finding festivals in town to walk around in. Free concerts in the park. Having girls night in instead of going out. I live near natural rivers so we would go to the river on the weekends and bring some sandwiches and some beers.   I had to cut out a lot in grad school but these were good ways to get out of the house and get in social interaction with friends on a small budget! Hopefully one of these may work for you!

Older Gen-X.  No one in my age group  was even thinking of buying a house at 25.  As teenagers we drove ugly embarrassingly bad used cars - we called them Hoopties back in the day. Not uncommon to have a rusted out hole in the floorboard you could see the street through!  I didn‚Äôt know anyone who bought a new car.  During and right after college we lived in rat trap apartments with zero amenities, worse than the average section 8 apartment now days.  No dishwasher or laundry-definitely no pool or gym. I had to light my ancient over with match and make toast in the living room because there were no plugs in the kitchen. It‚Äôs just the way it was and we didn‚Äôt expect more until we paid our dues and got to a better stage. And we were mostly middle class kids raised in solidly middle class homes. But starting out we knew we were going to have to start building from the bottom.   We didn‚Äôt expect ‚Äúnice things‚Äù and struggle was just part of this phase of life.  It made us able to face challenges head on as we got older.

Your health, mental health, your finances... we are not entitled to anything, we have to work for it, and happiness is a side effect of meaning. ‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†¬†@Star_Rattler¬† That‚Äôs very interesting. I suppose always genuinely smiling at work almost necessarily has to be performative, as one cannot always be expected to be happy at a job.  I ended up writing a lot, more than I expected, so sorry in advance! I got the impression from reading that the act of smiling seems slightly difficult, or at least not easy, and it was the same for me in the past but no longer, and I wrote mostly about the progression in hopes that it could be useful or at least interesting to read about.  My mother mentioned to me years ago as a teenager that my neutral face could be very scary, and similarly to what you mentioned, I would have it even when happy. I‚Äôm not exactly sure how I came to my understanding of how facial muscles work, but I changed my neutral expression to be less scary and more‚Ä¶ neutral. Muscles can be extended or contracted, and they lengthen or shorten based on their ‚Äútraining‚Äù. As in, the neutral position of a muscle is not absolute and unchanging. Take the tongue, for example. The optimal tongue posture has the tongue curved and touching the roof of the mouth, but some maladaptive postures have it flat and pushed against the teeth, which causes some facial development issues like stunting jaw development or splitting apart the two front teeth over time (I used to do this). After starting to move my tongue to the correct posture, though, eventually that‚Äôs where it rested neutrally as the muscles adjusted, and my tongue no longer ever tended to lie flat.   I write all this about the tongue because I believe the same applies to the muscles of the face. Partially, though, I was backtracking how I got to this point, as I assume learning from tongue posture back then helped with later changes. My neutral face had the muscles of my mouth almost fully extended, appearing to droop. What I changed was just‚Ä¶ to not let them droop all the way, but actually hold them in the middle between fully smiling and fully drooping. Nowadays I look like I‚Äôm sliiiiiightly smiling. I think of this similarly to abdominal muscles, where the ideal is to slightly tense them and maintain better posture rather than allow your abs to sag completely.   Some muscles that are involved in truly smiling are involuntary, so there will always be some performative aspect to smiling if you‚Äôre not actually happy, but I do believe it‚Äôs possible to not have a scary or sad neutral face through just slightly changing posture and changing the natural resting state of muscles over time. I hope the read was at least somewhat interesting if not useful!

As a neurodivergent person, this is not about not being naturally good at socializing. Not everyone naturally appears the same as neurodivergent people (otherwise that behavior wouldn't be divergent). This is a generation that was poorly socialized as children. The rise in only children growing up alone trapped inside a suburban house, legally mandated helicopter parenting, loss of child friendly third places, loss of independent mobility for children. This is the result of a thing we did to children, not a thing that children are or were.   It's also not the kids fault. This is the fault of parents, lawmakers, and lobbyists.

I once had to explain why gen z americans are so unpatriotic to my gen x dad. I told him that we've never had a reason to be. We were toddlers at best when 9/11 happened, so we don't remember the surge of national pride that followed. What we remember is the long-term aftermath: the surveillance state, increased islamophobia, everything in the middle east, etc. The news about Abu Ghraib broke in 2004. We've never seen patriotism used for good, we've only seen it mask nationalism that is used for cruelty and exploitation. Sometimes this makes us cynical and apathetic, but I think it also helps us ignore national borders. Other than ironic feuds with the British and jokes about the Olympics, many of us have very little loyalty to an arbitrary national identity. When we see people suffering, like those in Gaza, we don't care if they're our country's allies or not. I think that can be a very powerful thing.

We need to SUPPORT YOUNG PEOPLE. To be CRYSTAL FUCKING CLEAR, "support young people" doesn't mean "pat them on the back and tell them they are the future." We must stop kicking the can down the road and stand with them, not just hand them the reigns and hope for the best. Time really is a circle, as others have pointed out the experiential divide between gen z and millennials is practically nonexistent.   I was in high school for the occupy wall street movement, in college for the first election of DJT.  And I cared, persistently, year after year. I got tired, I feel hopelessness regularly. But after a decade of toiling I am 6 months away from being an attorney for low income tenants. I will help keep dozens of people housed just in my first year. That won‚Äôt fix the world, but it‚Äôll make it just a tiny bit better.  Ultimately, that‚Äôs all we can do. Find your lane, and do what you can with what you have. You‚Äôll even find community on the other side of people doing the exact same thing as you.

The thing about empathy is that it took me a long time and a depressive episode to realize that empathy connects you to others, but if those others are in pain, it causes you pain. And people can only take so much pain before they go numb. The internet connects us to a lot of people. The numbness of every generation that has grown up online seems to be consequential.

Let's not forget either that the protests to end the war in Vietnam were not taken seriously until the protests at Kent State that was televised where everyone saw the national guard shooting at the protesters. Even though the protest was not intended to be violent, because of the violence caused by the police and seen in everyone's living rooms, that was what really got America paying attention and listening to the students. Nixon started pulling people out of Vietnam in the wake of that protest, and the reaction that followed.

I think we are about the same age. I am 30. I feel the exact same way. I recently moved to LA where the homelessness is really bad and it made me SO FUCKING MAD, and depressed; depressed to see such suffering. on a daily basis. My best friend worked at a homeless shelter, and I volunteered one day. I have been doing it ever since. I also want to get more involved in climate change. For the first time I felt less crazy - I was with a bunch of other ppl who saw the broken system for what it was. I felt less alone and less sad. Amazing work you will be doing!

@ We are the same age! I‚Äôm happy to hear you volunteered and got involved. If you want to deepen your involvement, I would research what issue coalitions exist in LA and get involved with those, as well. They‚Äôre often the ones working behind the scenes to get local and state laws passed to address problems.   For example, the tenant orgs I‚Äôve worked at so far as a student are all a part of coalitions centered around housing. The most famous one here is probably the Right to Counsel NYC coalition, which successfully made it law that low income tenants have a right to an attorney in eviction proceedings. The organizing and lobbying these local coalitions do can be great catalysts for change.

This is exactly why its so important to unplug from the Internet and to keep your in person friends close. We are social creatures, and social media is the largest double edged sword we've ever created. In small doses it can generate great empathy, but too much has the opposite effect and burns you out, just as you explained.  Put down the phone, make your time intentional and things get a whole lot more manageable. Those 30 minutes you spent scrolling TikTok could've been used to cook a meal, read a chapter in a book, or hell just to play video games or do something that's actually relaxing and not mind numbing.  Work/life balance is important, just as important as internet/life balance imo. An imbalance in either can royally screw up a person's mental health

I've hit rock bottom before, and I've promised myself never to go that low again. The things your mind does to you when you're in that state are disgusting. Thoughts I wouldn't wish on my worst enemies. The brain is a crazy thing, it can bring immense harm and even greater good. Only you can pick what road to walk.

It's so beautiful to see somebody write like I do. I don't know how to explain this to you, but I've written paragraphs with the exact adjectives and writing style of this. I think I just found another human who seems to understand balance at its core, and why rock bottom brings out life even more.

Truth be told, you never know where rock bottom is unless you already changed for the better. Sometimes that low is so low that you can never even reach your former peak. Think about someone that was in a terrible accident and now can no longer walk and has brain damage.
You cant gain anything until you've lost everything

Respectfully, rock bottom is only "beautiful" in hindsight, if you manage to scrape yourself out of it. Romanticizing it is not a good idea, because part of the trick of "rock bottom" is that there is no bottom to reach: it can always get worse. Hitting that low point just makes it all the clearer what the consequences of failure are, because they're a sword held above your head ready to fall if you continue to get things wrong.
I always wanted to hit the rock bottom, that feels like my only way to push myself into changing, yet it is very scary, so I have to start right here right now
The best thing about rock bottom is that there is only one way out. Look up

And the best thing about rock bottom is that you can raise its floor so the bottom isn‚Äôt so deep you can‚Äôt climb out of it. Every time you hit it, raise it up. Don‚Äôt let being homelessness be your bottom, raise the floor.

Sometimes the terrifying part is that you're going down slowly in life, and you don't feel like it's rock bottom yet. It's perhaps never coming, and it'll be worse; there will never be a life-changing moment that forces you to change as if you're not allowed to completely shatter. The cracks just kept spreading.

As someone with blatant ADHD, I found that when I do a project, the best motivation to actually finish it, is to just start it immediately (before I've even finished planning it, when I'm most excited to actually do it and before I lose interest) and leave it in the middle of my workspace. I don't even have all the parts yet, but this incomplete mess inconveniences me, and it will continue to get in my way daily until it's fully assembled and completed. If I pack it up into some box and throw it into the basement and say "eh I'll get back to it later, I need the space for something else," that day will never happen.  In short, "lock in" on your current project until it's done. Don't put it away and start a new one in the middle because you'll "get back to it," and don't hesitate to get started on it just because you haven't planned everything out to perfection and analyzed every possible snag. By the time you complete a plan that thorough you'll have lost interest, so just start now and plan as you go! (This is a common problem with perfectionist types)

humans want to be comfortable, not happy.  and we find comfort in what we are used to doing, (scrolling on tiktok, sitting around, gamimg, etc) not a new thing, that sure, it would be better for us, but our subconscious doesn't know that. that's why you hear a lot of fitness or life coaches say "get out of your comfort zone" bc you LITERALLY have to do that!  and don't just do everything at once. start with something that is small and easy to change. for example, instead of deleting tiktok, set a time limit on it. and when that time limit is done, go do something else. or maybe you want to start going to the gym, but in reality you should work on consistency first by going for a 10 min walk every single day for 2 weeks. then you can try going to the gym 3 times a week. once you start small, it's easy to work your way up to something big.  and don't wait for motivation, the motivation will come to you naturally once you actually start doing something.  and force yourself to do it anyway, even when you are tired. consistency is WAY more important than instant results.

That‚Äôs what locking in is.   You lock your focus on the thing you want.  It is probably the only way the most of us will ever have the life you want.   It‚Äôs hard work and that‚Äôs because hard work is how you get good things.  I had to lock in to lose 60lbs and I am about as far from hustle culture as you can get.  Locking in just means focusing on yourself goal and move toward it a bit each day.   You can even fail but if you are locked in you get up and keep going. It's my 2 year anniversary of being locked in, I think I got 3 more to go but honestly might just stay here. Word of advice to anyone that may be reading, don't try to give up distractions, just take control of what distracts yo u and allow yourself to be distracted occasionally. The grind feels badass, but if you never stop to allow yourself to be swept up by life, you'll reach the other of the two extremes and feel like you're not quite living. I'm not sure how to explain this, but it's so important, so I'll try; there's a certain ability which is very hard to gain conscious control over, it feels like uncoiling the spring on the minds clockwork, a very deliberate investment in allowing all your senses to feel. Honestly, it's also a type of focus; there comes a point where the focus on the grind becomes so distracting that all your channels of orientation within reality become dampened. When the quality of your reality suffers, you subconsciously lose some of your motivation to remain at your task within it. Enough focus to realize that you're human, with human limitations, and wind back the pendulum swing trying to view the opposite extreme as the easy fix. Changing one's mindset isn't enough, we have to be able to cultivate our reactions, perceptions, ideals; in order to find balance. Shifting just enough to not fall over. If you never focus to deliberately chill out, you'll never be able to really lock in.   Running at 50%, 85% of the time. Took a long time to get to that point. Even running at 40%, 60% of the time seems to be better than what most are doing; certainly better than running at 110%, 1% of the time (we all started there, it's miserable). You WILL need to be delusional if you're set on turning a want into a need; and that comes with its own downsides, the main one being that actual needs become neglected once you're willing to literally throw your life away in pursuit of a dream. Hold on the just enough realism to realize that dreams cannot be pursued by a dead man. In hindsight, it's crazy feeling like you're starving because you took some time to eat and stay healthy; but it's also one of the best feelings, because that's what purpose feels like. Don't let purpose kill you, don't let yourself die without it. Cheers.

I think also discuss how it feels like innovation will continue on one particular realm endlessly but there are physical limits. Rockets will improve linearly for a time then reach some cap of our current understanding then stagnate. This is what happened with self driving cars, they were improving so fast we felt the improvement would continue forever, then it hit a cap both in hardware and software. Driving turned out to be such a more complicated problem than we initially thought.

+DonCDXX The problem is the second part requires high levels of education and a certain minimum level of intelligence or capability that not everyone will be able to meet, hence I have concerns about unemployment as automation continues to pervade society.

As human beings are phased out of more and more aspects of the economy, the cost to deliver goods and services will be going down. Competition will ensure that the savings is passed on to consumers. Therefore people will need less income in order to afford the same quality of life. That is to say, they can work for a lower hourly rate and maintain the same quality of life. And when they're working at a lower hourly rate, the cost incentive to automate is reduced, and the pace of automation is tempered. The takeaway from all of this is that deflation is inevitable, and nothing the Fed does can prevent it. The harder it tries to fight deflation, the more fucked up things will be, that's my view.
